Jack had to admit that Dane was making a good point, "You're probably right. It looks fine out there."

Jack and Dane decided against the news anchor's warnings and went outside to go to school. They walked for about five minutes and everything seemed fine. There were other people on the streets and life seemed to be going on as it usually does.

Suddenly Dane yelled, "What the fuck is that?"

At twenty-five years old, she was lucky to have such a privileged position at the Center for Unusual Microbiology, but she knew she was really just a glorified intern. All sorts of fascinating research was done at the facility, but all she ever got to do was grunt work.

Tonight she'd been left behind, alone, to organize specimens in some forgotten corner of the lab. The room she was in looked old, dusty, and unused, and didn't seem at all to be the sort of place that people ought to be storing valuable and potentially dangerous specimens. Still, she was almost done for the evening, and her boyfriend Darren would be coming to pick her up soon. Just one freezer remained, a tiny one tucked inconspicuously in a far corner of the room. As she went to open the door of the freezer - which, unlike the others, looked rather like it had been used recently - a mouse darted out from under a nearby table and ran straight towards her foot.

"YEEEK! Ugh! This place really is unsanitary!"

If Helga had had more presence of mind in that moment, she might have been thankful that no one else was there to hear her embarrassing squeal. Then again, if she'd had more presence of mind, she probably wouldn't have crashed into a shelf full of chemicals while jumping back to avoid the mouse, either. The rickety shelf toppled over on her, knocking her down under its weight. As they both went down, the shelf also hit the freezer, tipping it forward and causing it to spill some jars onto the floor where they smashed open and added their contents to those of the broken bottles from the shelf in a puddle around Helga's fallen form.

"This is just like... a superhero origin story..." Helga thought to herself just before she blacked out.

“This has to be a dream,” she kept repeating. “This is all just a dream. I passed out when all that stuff fell on me, and I’m still unconscious. Maybe I’ll wake up… now!”

“…Now!”

“Okay, now!”

Nothing was happening. Despite the clear impossibility of her current circumstance, it was evidently happening all the same. She was trying to come up with a plan of action, but she was too freaked out to think straight. The last place she remembered being was the lab… That was it! The lab! She didn’t know what was happening, but if any place had the answers, it would be there. That meant she’d have to go out, though… would people notice her ‘condition’ ?

First off, she’d have to put clothes on. She grabbed a random shirt and a pair of pants out of the closet. That was one upside of being a boy, she supposed – picking a good outfit took no effort at all. She didn’t bother with a change of underwear; she wasn’t quite ready to see Darren’s genitals from this new perspective just yet. Although she didn’t know what good it would do, she couldn’t resist looking herself over in the floor-length mirror she discovered on the inside of the closet door.

She may not have put any thought into the outfit, but it still looked pretty good, she had to say. The acid-washed skinny jeans went well with stylish designer t-shirt. The only thing ‘off’ was her head.

Helga leaned in close for a better look. She had no makeup, glasses, or earrings on at present (all of which she'd had last night), and her hair wasn’t tied back like it usually was. Still, it was definitely her head, and looked like her neck as well. That would explain why her voice sounded the same… Come to think of it, how was it she could see without her glasses, anyhow? Did she somehow inherit Darren’s eyesight, while keeping her eyes? That didn’t make sense – but then, nothing about this did.

She took a deep breath. Was she ready to go out? Maybe people wouldn’t notice her if she acted casually. Maybe, if they did notice her, they would just think she was a man with a feminine face or a woman with a masculine body. Maybe she should’ve found something more androgynous to wear. Does Darren have a hoodie, she wondered? That would help disguise her head, and obscure the shape of her torso as well. She looked around, but didn’t see one anywhere in the room. 1533123132222211.content:
Soon the four Helgas were all seated around a table in the cafeteria.

"Alright, 'ladies', it's clear that we need some kind of a plan," said Helga number one. "We, or rather, I, have a dangerous power that we need to keep contained. We also need to figure out how to undo the damage that's already been done, if that's even possible. But before we can do either of those things, we need to figure out what exactly this is."

"Well clearly, you - wow, it feels so weird talking to myself like that - were exposed to something in the lab that has triggered this reaction of copying yourself onto anyone you touch." said Dr. Helga. "I would guess that it's a modified virus, or something similar. Fortunately, it seems to be confined to just the original Helga, which will help limit its spread. But the way in which it behaves is most curious, I must say."

"That's putting it mildly," said Nurse Helga. "I guess I'm the youngest of us, so to speak, but I've been thinking - as I'm sure you all have - and I'd like to sum up what I've noticed so far about the way this... virus works. If the rest of you know anything else, please let me know." The other Helgas nodded.

"Well, first of all," she continued, "as...um...other Helga said, the potential to create new Helgas is limited to the original. Second, from listening to you talk, it seems that none of us have any memories from later than last night. By that I mean that every time a new clone is formed, the last thing we remember is always the accident - if Original Me were to touch someone else right now and make another copy, she would come into existence without any of the knowledge we've gained since then. She wouldn't recall this conversation, for instance."

She paused and glanced around to make sure everyone was still on the same page. Since their brains were all identical, she suspected they were.

"Third, for whatever reason, no one else seems to notice anything amiss. Cloned Mes are still seen by others as the people they used to be, even if the cloning occurs right in front of them."

"It is very strange how other people don't seem to notice any change," said Original Helga. "I can't imagine what could possibly explain that phenomenon. It's enough to make a girl believe in magic."

"I'm also wondering why the cloning process only affects the head, and not the rest of the body." Said Dr. Helga. "Then again, I guess you all must be wondering that, too, since you're all me as well."

Helga!Darren sort of timidly raised his/her hand. "Is anyone else worried about the people we've, um, replaced? I don't mean to get all philosophical, but what happened to their original minds? Have we just...over-written them? Do you think they might still be conscious somehow? Or are they... dead?"

"The way I see it," said Helga with the nurse's body, "there are two possibilities. One is that we really still are these people, but the transformation made us lose all our original memories and gain 'Original' Helga's memories instead, so we all think we're her. The other is that we're newly created copies and wholly new people, in which case we replaced these bodies' original owners, in which case: yeah, they're basically dead. If it's the first, then we haven't really stolen these bodies, so that's good; if it's the second, well, they're dead anyway and there's nothing that can be done now. Either way, I don't see the point in worrying."

"That's an awfully callous thing to say!" Said Helga One. "These are lives we're talking about here!"

"I'm surprised you don't feel the same way," said Helga the nurse. "Shouldn't we all have the same opinions about everything?"

"But there's more to it than that," Darren!Helga continued. "I also meant that we've taken over these people's lives without necessarily knowing the first thing about them." She gestured to the doctor and nurse Helgas. "Now you two are stuck as doctor and a nurse, and you don't even know their names, let alone have their training! Aren't you worried about that?"

"Crap, you're right!" Said Helga with the doctor's body. "I got so caught up in the weirdness of it all that I forgot all about that. I can't go through the rest of the day as this guy!"

"Well obviously this is a big problem for all of us," said Helga 1, "but I think we can all agree that if there are any answers to be found, they'll be found back at the lab. 'Darren' and I will head back there now. Feel free to join us if you can get out of work."

"I'd better get out of here soon," said Dr. Helga, looking down at 'her' body. "I just hope I'm not a heart surgeon or something really important."

"Finally. It's ready for testing!" Helga exclaimed as she finished making adjustments on her latest project. She had been working with her friend and fellow scientist, Emma, to build a prototype of the first fully functional teleportation machine. The machine consists of two human-sized pods which are wirelessly connected to a laptop running software that controls the pods. The idea is to find a way to remove the laptop once the duo have proven that the machine works and secure funding for mass production.

"Will you do the honours, Helga?" Emma gestures towards one of the open pods. Both have been placed next to each other for the sake of testing, but the plan is to have the pods located long distances away from each other. Helga and Emma hope to make the pods synchronise successfully, even from the other side of the planet.

Helga climbs into one of the pods and closes the glass door behind her. "Are you ready?" Emma asks. Helga nods in response and Emma begins booting up the pods. There is a whiring sound coming from the top of Helga's pod as the machine that breaks down the atoms in her body begins to rotate faster and faster. Suddenly, Helga is blinded by a bright light, before everything goes dark and silent. From Emma's point of view, Helga disintegrates, leaving only a cloud of smoke behind. Helga's point of view however, was very different as she experiences her body and consciousness being suspended in what feels like another dimension. The experience was brief though, as seconds later, Helga rematerialises inside the adjacent pod.

"It work. It actually worked!!!" Helga exclaims in excitement at the success of her new invention. As her initial excitement wears off though, she quickly discovers that something was wrong and that the machine hadn't worked as well as she originally believed.

1533321.title: Suzanne Wong, 40, businesswoman

15333211.content:
Suzanne Wong took another bite of her chicken wrap as she walked back towards her office. She was later than she had intended; the new corner place that she'd decided to try for lunch had good food, it seemed, but slow service.

Admittedly, though she didn't want to be late for the meeting, she still sort of hoped that she could get out of it somehow, and was actually - despite the constant worrying of the rational part of her brain - a little bit glad to be delayed. At least she could claim that it wasn't her fault (although if she really was late, she wasn't sure they'd care what the excuse was).

I really shouldn't be worried about this, she tried to tell herself. Whatever happens, happens. Worrying is just going to give me more gray hairs. Suzanne had never thought of herself as very appearance-oriented before, but ever since she turned 40 she had secretly been getting more concerned. In truth, she probably had even less to worry about than most: age had only granted her Asian features an air of distinction and maturity, and had taken none of her youthful good looks. Her own mother had been well into her sixties before age had started to take its toll in earnest. Still... Suzanne spent more time than she cared to admit leaning in front of the mirror with her glasses off, squinting and grimacing to look for imagined wrinkles.

As she passed a glass storefront, she paused to check her reflection. Everything looked OK, except that the bun she'd pulled her hair back into was starting to loosen, and a lock of her dark hair was hanging down in front of her forehead. Before she could fix anything, her high heel shoe twisted underneath her and she stumbled. She caught herself before she went down, but not before she dropped a big glob of sauce from her chicken wrap right on her suit jacket.

"Shit! This is just what I needed right now... guess that's what I get for not looking where I'm going." She dabbed at the sauce with a napkin, but the stain remained.
Suddenly, she was aware of somebody in front of her.

"Excuse me, madam," came a voice. Suzanne looked up to see the rattiest, dirtiest, most stereotypical homeless man she'd ever seen. His face was so caked in dirt that Suzanne couldn't tell what his natural skin tone was. It was equally impossible to determine what his coat had originally been made of - it looked like an old rug now. He spoke again.

"I sincerely beg your pardon, but... might I have even one small bite of that sandwich of yours? I cannot remember when I last ate... I am so hungry, but everyone I have approached has ignored me. Please, good lady, have some mercy on this poor soul, you may be my only hope."

Suzanne couldn't help but feel a twinge of sympathy. Something about his plight resonated with her. She couldn't count the number of times she felt ignored, both at work and at home. Plus, as bad as she had just been feeling, here was someone who was obviously having a worse day than her.

"Here," she said. "Actually, take the whole thing." It might have been prejudiced, but she didn't really want it back after he'd had a bite. The dirt was one thing, but there was something else about him that seemed... uncanny. Besides, it was better to give him the whole thing anyway, rather than just a bite. Suzanne was hungry herself, but it wouldn't be hard to get more.

"Oh, thank you so much!" cried the strange man, grabbing the partially eaten chicken wrap with ravenous glee. "Your kindness will be rewarded one day, I am sure of it!" He vanished around a corner.

Suzanne looked down at her watch. "Shit, I have to hurry!" She walked on as fast as she dared in her heels, dreading the impending meeting. Little did she know that the old man to whom she had shown kindness was actually a djinn in disguise, and had resolved to grant her next wish in thanks. Before this day was over, Suzanne's life would change in a big way.

Later that afternoon, after the meeting had let out, Suzanne was slumped back in her office chair, staring at the ceiling. As she had feared, the meeting with the executives had put a lot more work on her plate, and she wasn't sure how she'd get it all done in time. She sighed. How had it even come to this? Financially she was doing quite well for herself, and she was good at her job. But it hadn't been what she had wanted, back when she was an idealistic young student. Her first passion had been biology, and she'd always imagined herself out in the field documenting rare and exotic species - or failing that, a lab somewhere, doing all kinds of exciting research. She'd also entertained the idea of being an artist (she supposed everyone entertained that idea at some point), but she'd never so much as taken a class. After graduating, though, with the job market being what it was, it had become clear that she couldn't be picky with the job offers. So, she'd accepted an entry-level position for some big corporation, and now here she was.

She looked down at her phone and noticed a new message. She sighed again when she saw it was from her husband, Mike. As if she didn't have enough to worry about at work, her home life had also been somewhat rocky of late. She and Mike weren't getting along like they used to - it seemed that Mike was becoming distant, and she had no idea why.

Feeling overwhelmed, Suzanne leaned forward and massaged her head with her hands. "Ugh," she groaned, "I wish..."
15333211.title: Wish

1533321111.title: College

15333211111.content:
“God, I wish I was back in school,” Suzanne groaned, cradling her face with her hands. Everything had been so much fun then, back when the future had been full of potential. She really should have changed majors from business and become a biologist like she’d really wanted. Or gotten into the arts, even. But she’d been afraid, and stuck to the easy path, and now it was too late. Fresh out of school she’d still humored the idea of going back at some point, but now she was 40, twice married, with two kids from the first one (one of whom was in college now himself… was she really that old?)… it didn’t seem right. And besides, she made pretty good money where she was now – more than a person would make conducting studies in some jungle somewhere. Somewhat reluctantly, she pulled herself out of her reverie and got back to work.

The rest of the day wasn’t any better than the beginning, although it wasn’t much worse, either. When Suzanne got home, it felt as if it had been years since she had left that morning. Her husband Mike got dinner started while she went upstairs to change out of her work clothes. She had underestimated how tired she really was, though – no sooner had she sat down on the bed, than she lay down and fell asleep.

The morning sun was a rude awakening to Suzanne. Following a few milliseconds of confusion, the events of the previous evening came flooding back to her. “Shit,” she muttered under her breath, “did I actually sleep the whole night? Suzanne stopped outside the door to the shop. This was the address she’d been given, no doubt about that. Looking at the place, she supposed it made sense why Gina had recommended it to her. The place was a quaint sidewalk shop, its storefront painted in purple with celestial designs. In the store window were some eclectic artifacts: here a stack of old books, there what appeared to be an idol of some kind, and nearest to the door, an old mannequin in an outfit that belonged on a storybook witch (pointy hat and everything). The store sign read: Laveau’s Magic and Mystery.

A bell jingled as she walked in the front door. Inside the shop was dim and musty, with a peculiar smell that Suzanne assumed was some kind of incense. All kinds of exotic and antique-looking curios surrounded her – on shelves, on tables, even on the floor. To inventory them all seemed like it would take months. All this place needs is a mogwai in a cage, Suzanne thought. She wasn’t sure she’d be that surprised if she found one. She picked her way through a maze of shelves, trying to adjust to the dimness. There was no outside light in here – a wall behind the display blocked any from coming in the front window, and the door was solid wood. Suzanne realized that she couldn’t think of a time when she’d been inside a store that you couldn’t see into from outside. Was that even legal? She supposed that it must be, but there was something about it that made her uneasy. It was not terribly comforting to think about what it might be that the store didn’t want passersby seeing…

At the counter was a college-aged girl with a black t-shirt and glasses. “Can I help you?” she asked uncertainly.

Suzanne wasn’t really sure what to say. “Er… can I speak to the proprietor, please? Are they here?”

The girl turned toward a door behind her. “Miss Laveau!” she called. “Someone wants to talk to you!”

Miss Laveau, the apparent owner of this curious establishment, entered almost immediately. She was an affable-looking black woman who looked to be in her forties but was still slim and fit. Suzanne wasn’t really sure what she’d been expecting – an old crone, perhaps, or something like a voodoo priestess, or maybe even a matronly white woman with loose purple clothing and an excess of gaudy jewelry – but this woman just looked so normal. She returned with the store’s proprietor in tow, who smiled at her pleasantly. “Ah, Miss… Suzanne, right? I have something for you.”

She reached under the counter and pulled out Suzanne’s necklace. Something was different about it, though. Whereas before it had been a plain gold chain, now it was adorned by a single small gem, red and teardrop-shaped.

“As you can see,” Ms. Laveau went on, “I’ve made some modifications. I now believe that you can use this to swap heads with anyone you wish, without taking the necklace off. Here.” She handed the necklace to Suzanne, who quickly put it on. It felt like she was reattaching a part of her body that had been missing.

“Now give it a try,” said Ms. Laveau. “Alice, if you wouldn’t mind…” Alice took up position across from Suzanne, looking reluctant but resigned. “Now just focus on the necklace, and imagine your head on her body.” Suzanne imagined.

Suddenly there was a rush, as if she were falling forward. Only her head seemed to be moving, though. Before she could take stock of it, it was over and Suzanne found herself standing where Alice had been just a second ago. Sure enough, there was Alice standing across from her – head now securely attached to Max’s body. She didn’t make any noise this time, but she hardly seemed thrilled. Suzanne looked down at her new female body. She resisted the urge to touch it this time. The necklace was still around her neck, and she thought she saw the gem glowing faintly for just a second.

“There, it works! Now, to swap back, just do the same as before.” Suzanne looked at Alice on her old body, felt her head slide forward for the briefest moment, and then Suzanne was perched on Max’s male frame once more. The necklace had traveled with her.

“According to my tests, everyone will see you as the rightful owner of the body you occupy. That is, if you’d stayed swapped with Alice, other people would see you as her.”

“This is amazing!” Suzanne exclaimed. With this, she could be anyone she wanted. She might even be able to get her old body back, if she could track it down.

153332113212.content:
Suzanne looked down – and screamed. Or rather, she took a long second to process what she was seeing, then screamed. Below her neck was a green stalk with leaves sprouting out of it, growing up out of the soil. She tried to move her head, but it was clear that her head was attached to the stem, connecting right where her neck should be. Her head – and only her head, with no other body parts in sight – surmounted the stalk like a flower. “Holy shit,” Suzanne cried, “I’m a plant!”

At least an hour – or so it felt (she had no way to be sure) – had passed, and Suzanne was still struggling to take stock of her situation. Tears welled in her eyes, but she had managed to restrain herself from full-on crying. Here was what she understood so far: She was now a plant. What kind, she didn’t know. She could feel her new ‘body’, as weird as that felt, but movement was extremely limited. Apart from her head, she could wiggle her leaves a little and twist her stem awkwardly, but anything else was out of the question. She was also very small – most other plants (none of which, as far as she could tell, had formerly been people) loomed above her, and at one point a rabbit had gotten close enough for her to tell that it was nearly as big as she was. So she was tiny and immobile, and alone in an unknown wilderness.

The one thing she still had was her human head. And for perhaps the last ten minutes, she had been using it as best she could. “Help!” she cried out. “Somebody please help me!”

She yelled like her life depended on it, because as far as she knew, it did. “Please, somebody help! I can’t move! Follow my voice!” She knew adding ‘I’ve been turned into a plant!’ wouldn’t help her cause, even if it was true. She didn’t know if anybody could hear her at all. After a few more minutes she fell silent, electing to save her voice for now.

Suzanne looked around her again; it wasn’t as though there was much else she could do. The scene was tranquil, idyllic even – were it not for the nightmare of her current situation. She wondered what kind of trees these were, growing around her, and what kinds of birds she could hear singing. She regretted not learning more about nature in her forty years of life. In any case, she was starting to feel a little calmer. She turned her awareness inward and focused on the feelings of her new plant body. She took a deep breath (how was she breathing without lungs?) as she felt out the sensations of her stem and leaves. She could feel her roots spreading under the ground, and felt dampness where the deepest ones were currently absorbing water. She even thought that she could feel water traveling up her stem, although perhaps that was just her imagination. Suddenly, the sun came out from behind the clouds. She hadn’t even realized that it had been all that cloudy until now, but now the sunlight was hitting her as if it was a physical force. She could feel it, warming her leaves and spreading into the rest of her. It felt…good.

“Ooh,” she said, as a curious feeling overtook her. It felt like warmth, but also happiness and contentment. It felt like she had just finished eating her favorite meal, or like memories of her childhood. It felt the way a picture of a Swiss mountain landscape looked, the way a new air freshener smelled. ‘Euphoria’ was the only way she could describe it. She didn’t think she had ever felt this good in her life.

The sun felt warm on her face as well. That sensation, at least, was familiar. She tilted her head back with a smile right as a butterfly passed overhead. Maybe it was just the way she felt in that moment, but it seemed like the most beautiful butterfly Suzanne had ever seen. She closed her eyes, felt the wind gently tease at her hair, and sighed blissfully. Maybe this part of being a plant – just this one, specific part – wasn’t so bad.

Suddenly,

1533321132121.content:
Suzanne heard a buzzing. It sounded like a bee, but larger – which made sense, as she was smaller now. She looked around nervously. She had never liked bees. Would it sting her? Would it…try to pollinate her? Stop worrying so much, she told herself. It’ll probably just pass by without even –

Suzanne stumbled in sudden shock. Her point of view had shifted abruptly. Her six legs scrabbled for purchase in the confusion – wait, WHAT? Suzanne’s breath caught in her throat: her body felt different. She could move now, but she did not like what she was feeling. She heard herself whimper a little as she turned her head to look at her new body…

Her head didn’t turn that well in its new setting, but she could see enough. Six legs. Translucent, veiny wings. A body encased in black-and-yellow chitin, with a coating of short hairs. There was no mistaking that body, or the fact that it was now hers. She was a bee. “AAAAAGH!” She screamed, not quite as loud as she had when she had found herself a plant. “Why am I a bee? I hate bees!” She had just started to adjust to being a plant, and now she was a bug and panicking again. The breeze in her hair, the faint pressure of her glasses, and the taste of her lipstick told her that once again she retained her human head, although now she also felt what must be two antennae protruding from her forehead. Trying to get her bearings, she wiggled her new abdomen and buzzed her wings experimentally (without lifting off). Then she looked down. The last thing she had felt as a plant was the sensation of a bee landing on her head. Was she now that bee? If that was the case, then what was she standing on?
1533321132121.title: A bee tries to land on her.

15333211321212.content:
“Umm…excuse me?” Under her feet was another Suzanne: a copy of her head larger than the bee’s entire body. It was attached to a long green stalk that descended down to the dirt below. It was Suzanne as a plant – the Suzanne that she herself had been maybe a second ago.

“Uh…hello,” Suzanne the bee said to her former herbaceous self.

“Oh my God,” said Plant-Suzanne. “Did I turn you into me?”

“Who’s ‘you’?” Bee-Suzanne asked in return.

“Me!”

“You’re not me, I’m me!”

“We’re both me!”

At this the two Suzannes simultaneously broke out into laughter. Laughing felt good. For a few brief moments they (she?) forgot to be worried… but that didn’t last long.

“So what, exactly, is going on here?” Plant-Suzanne asked her insect double.

“Dunno,” Suzanne’s second head said from her bee body. “I know as much as you do. Until a second ago, I WAS you!”

“Well, first I became a plant, then I guess I somehow…copied myself onto a bee.”

“Didn’t do it on purpose, that’s for sure,” said Bee-Suzanne as she recalled the moment before her transfer from plant to insect. “Hey, we might be contagious. Better be careful or there’ll be a whole slew of mes running around here in no time.”

“Not a whole lot I can do about that, seeing as I can’t move.” Plant-Suzanne paused. “Speaking of, do you mind getting off of my face?”

“Oh!” Bee-Suzanne immediately opened her wings and took off, so that she was now hovering in front of her other self. Suddenly it dawned on her what she’d just done. “Hey, I’m flying!”

“Rub it in, why don’t you?” Plant-Suzanne said sarcastically.

“Seriously, this is so amazing!” Bee-Suzanne did a few loop-the-loops before returning to position in front of her twin. “And it takes no effort at all! It’s like this body just knows how!”
“Don’t go nuts, now. If we can figure out what happened to us, we have to at least try.”

“I need to do some exploring,” said Bee-Suzanne, poorly attempting to hide her excitement. “Maybe I’ll see something.”

“Careful,” said Plant-Suzanne. “Remember what you said about being contagious. Before you know it I could be copied onto half the living things in this forest.”

“Mm, I dunno,” said Bee-Suzanne, looking thoughtful. “I’ve always thought our head was especially beautiful… it might improve a few of the creatures out here.”

“I’m you, so I know you’re just kidding.”

“Guess I can’t fool myself!” Bee-Suzanne looked back with a grin as she flew away. “Wish me luck!”

Plant-Suzanne smiled as she watched the bee with her head disappear into the distance. “I sure hope nothing eats her,” she said to herself.

1533321132231111.content:
Suzanne felt a sinking in her stomach as she thought of all the work she still had to do that day.

"Uuuuggh," she said, leaning back in her chair, "I wish I didn't have to worry about all this shit. Work, home, all this stress... I just wish I could live a life where I was free."

The words were barely spoken when she felt a wave of dizziness overwhelm her, like the feeling you get when you stand up too quickly after a long time. Great, now I'm getting headaches, Suzanne started to think, but the feeling didn't pass. Instead, it morphed into a peculiar light-headedness, accompanied by a cold feeling in her neck. Before Suzanne could worry about whether this was something more serious than a headache, she realized that the room was moving around her. It looked as if it was sinking; like the ceiling was descending on her.

Starting to panic, Suzanne tried to stand up only to discover that she could not. She looked down and screamed. Below her in the chair was a woman's body in the same suit she'd left the house in that morning, not limp, but sitting perfectly still. Suzanne knew it was her own body, but from her slowly rising viewpoint she could see that there was no head. Where her own head should have rested there was only smooth skin. Her office wasn't sinking, she was floating - but only her head was.

"What the Hell?!?" she cried. "Help! HELP!!!"

Suzanne continued to shout, but no help seemed to be coming. Meanwhile her head continued to rise. Not only was she unable to move or feel her body, but she didn't seem to have any control over what her head was doing, either. She had risen to a height of about seven feet and was now rotating towards the window.

"Oh, no," she said as she felt her head begin moving forward, towards the wall of (very emphatically closed) windows. "No, no, no... no no no NO!" She braced herself for impact as she approached with increasing speed, but at the last second she simply passed through the window as if it weren't there at all.

Suzanne was now flying over downtown, a disembodied head soaring high above the hustle and bustle below. She didn't know if anyone could see her, but she made sure to scream as loud as she could in case that helped. She was still picking up speed, and the wind buffeted her face and tousled her hair as she went faster and faster and faster. Buildings zipped by and then became a blur. When she couldn't stand the wind in her face any longer, she shut her eyes and prayed that her glasses stayed on.

Probably no more than a minute had passed when Suzanne felt that she was slowing down significantly. When she opened her eyes, she saw a peaceful suburban neighborhood spread out before her. Sure enough, whatever unknown force was controlling her head's flight path brought her back down to a comfortable speed. What's more, she found herself losing altitude until she was maybe forty feet above the yards below. She drifted over a number of suburban yard scenes - people sitting on patios, playing in pools, or barbecuing - but though she called out to everyone no one acknowledged her.

Finally she came to a stop. Suzanne felt that her heart must be beating a thousand beats a minute, until she remembered that her heart was back in her body an unknown distance away. In the yard below her, a little girl was playing with some toys while a large brown dog sniffed some bushes nearby. Suzanne's head began to descend.

"Hey! Hey kid! Please help me!" She yelled, though she wasn't surprised when she got no answer. Crap, she wondered, what's going to happen now? Skimming low over the grass, she realized she was making a beeline for the dog.

Like the girl, the dog seemed not to notice her presence. Instead it was going about its doggy business with a vacant 'smile' on its doggy face. Suzanne was closing in quick, and speeding up again. What was about to happen? Would she pass right through like she had with the window? The dog raised its head directly into Suzanne's path and for a second it looked like they'd collide, but then there was a bright flash of light and --

**********

A disoriented Suzanne blinked rapidly in a vain attempt to clear the spots from her eyes. She was still in the little girl's yard, just a few feet off the ground, but something felt very different. She took a clumsy step forward.

Wait. Step?

Yes, step. She had just moved. Suzanne was once more getting sensations from below her neck. She had a body again... except it wasn't hers. She could tell without looking that this wasn't her body, but then whose body was it? And why was she in this strange yard, seemingly standing on all fours?

Don't look down, a tiny part of her whispered. You already know what you're going to see, don't you? Ignoring her own advice, Suzanne looked down at what should have been her hands only to discover that she had none. In their place were two big, brown paws. Oh, no... Suzanne now realized what felt so wrong about her new body. She looked over her shoulder at the body of the dog, the same dog she thought she'd collide with just seconds ago. But now, it was her body.

Suzanne skipped the screaming and went straight into throwing up.

Holy shit! Oh my God! Am I a...DOG now? Is my head on this dog's body? This is a nightmare - has to be! I fell asleep at work and -

Suzanne was broken out of her terror by the sound of a little girl's voice.

"Riley?" It said.

15333211322312211.content:
Suzanne leaned back in her chair and sighed deeply. Was this the direction she wanted her life to take? Lately things had all just seemed so…pointless. “Some days I wish I could just start over,” she said to herself. She closed her eyes, just for a second…

Suddenly Suzanne was aware of pressure on all sides of her. She felt like she was wrapped tightly in something very heavy. Where was she? Had she fallen asleep? The last thing I remember… She tried to open her eyes, but there was nothing to see. She tried to move, but could barely wiggle. Something felt wrong with her body. Was she naked? Yes, she could feel the ‘walls’ of her prison, warm and slimy, on her bare skin – her clothes were all gone. That wasn’t all, though: her body itself felt strange, as if her proportions were wrong. And was there something attached to her stomach? She tried to move again, but her limbs (whatever state they were in) were pinned. Although naked, Suzanne could tell that she still had her glasses, since they were currently pressed quite uncomfortably against her face. She could also feel her hair bun pressing into the back of her head. She was having difficulty breathing, her face pressed up against what was now feeling like some kind of organic membrane. What was she wrapped in? What had happened to her?

Suddenly there was a heavy pulse and the walls around Suzanne contracted, pushing her forward. She hadn’t realized there was a forward until now. Another, smaller contraction pushed her a little further still. Suzanne became aware of noises now, noises that sounded an awful lot like muffled voices. As she listened she thought she could make out the sounds of a woman in distress, and another voice speaking calmly and firmly but also unintelligibly. Suzanne tried to squirm again and this time, for just a second, she thought she felt a tiny breath of cool air on the top of her head. Freedom! If she could just make it a few more feet…

Again the ‘tunnel’ spasmed and pushed her forward. Taking advantage of the momentary relaxation of pressure, Suzanne shifted her head so that she was facing forward. This time the momentary puff of cooler air kissed her face. And was she seeing things, or had there been a glimpse of light? Almost there, she thought. One more good push and I should at least have my head out. This is just like being – before she could finish the thought, she heard the voice again. It was still muffled, but she could make out words this time. “Just one more push!” It said, followed by another groan in the female voice. Wait, what? Was all Suzanne had time to think before the push came.

Suzanne gasped as her face and head protruded into the light and fresh air. “Here comes the head!” said the voice, clearly now. Suzanne tried to glance around – that was difficult, as there was mucus from the tunnel walls coating her glasses, but she could see enough. There were people in front of her, wearing medical scrubs. The bright lights were those of a hospital’s lights. But those details paled before the most relevant ones: the two bare legs of a woman, looming large on either side of her with the feet splayed out before her and the hips around her head. A sick sense of wonder took hold; Suzanne knew exactly where she was. She’d been here twice before, though not in this precise position. Well, actually, she had been in this position once as well, although she had no memory of it. “Alright, give me one last push!” Said the doctor, and with that the rest of Suzanne’s body was expelled from the strange woman’s vagina and birthed into the world.

The world was reeling as Suzanne was borne into the hands of giant-sized nurses. She looked down at her body and saw it was the doughy, stubby-limbed body of a newborn, covered in the slime of childbirth. Behind the umbilical cord was a tiny penis – this child was a boy. Her head, though it was also covered in slime, did not feel like a baby’s or a boy’s. Her mouth was full of teeth, the same teeth she’d had just a minute ago when she’d been sitting in her office chair. She was obviously still wearing glasses, certainly something no one had ever been born with before. And she could feel her long hair, with the hairpins keeping it in its bun, as well as the earrings that were somehow still in her ears. She was, it would seem, a baby boy with the head of a grown woman.

“It’s a boy,” said the doctor, “eight pounds eight ounces.”

Suzanne, like so many babies before her, cried.
15333211322312211.title: Born Again

153332113223122111.content:
“Well, his lungs seem to be working fine!” said one of the nurses, causing Suzanne to self-consciously choke back her next sob. She was acting like a baby. She didn’t want to be a baby.

The world spun around as she was passed to another nurse while the other one tied off her umbilical cord and cut it. Suzanne blushed as she felt the woman’s hand brush her tiny new penis. Anxious to be distracted by something she glanced over to the woman who was now, apparently, her mother. She looked young (though probably mid-twenties, which was older than Suzanne had been when she’d had her first child), Caucasian with brown hair. Her face was red with exhaustion, but it also bore a curious expression. She was staring at Suzanne with wide eyes – not simply the wonder of seeing her newborn child, but eyes wide with confusion and maybe even fear. She seemed as surprised as Suzanne, and when their eyes met, she started to raise her hand tentatively. Can she tell? Suzanne wondered. Nobody else in the room was acting like she was anything other than an ordinary baby. Suzanne tried to reach out to her, but her movements were slow and uncoordinated.

“W-what’s wrong?” asked the woman who had just given birth to her. “Something’s wrong!”

“Nothing’s wrong,” assured the doctor. “Everything’s completely fine.”
“But his head! Look at his head! It’s-“

“It’s normal for the head to be a bit deformed after coming out. The bones in the skull haven’t fused together yet, so they can be squeezed. He’ll look normal in a few hours.”

“No, that’s not what I…”the woman started before falling into a defeated silence.

Suddenly it occurred to Suzanne to try to speak. “Help!” she cried. “Can anyone hear me? Someone help!”

“Well, someone has a lot to say!” cooed a nurse. Wait, did that mean she could understand her or not?

“Hello?” Suzanne repeated. “Please tell me if you can understand what I’m saying right now!”

“Ssshhh” said the nurse, gently. “Ssshhh, it’s OK.” That sounded like a ‘no.’ Suzanne felt tears welling up. She looked back at her ‘mother’, who hadn’t stopped staring at her.

“Can you understand me?” Suzanne called out. “Just nod if you can understand me!” The woman nodded slowly. A spark of hope kindled inside Suzanne’s tiny new heart. Here was something she could grab onto, the first anchor point in this deranged nightmare that she now found herself in. To be honest she highly doubted this woman could give her any insight into what was happening, but at least – at the very least – she had someone she could talk to.

“Would you like to hold him?” asked the nurse. The woman nodded again, not breaking eye contact with Suzanne, and held out her arms. “We’ll leave the two of you alone for a little bit, said the nurse as she handed Suzanne to the stranger whose vagina she had just popped out of. The two women stared at each other.

“What the FUCK is going on??” croaked the woman in a hoarse, tired voice as soon as the others were out of earshot. “Who the fuck are you?”

“My name is Suzanne, and I don’t know what’s going on either!” The woman’s face loomed large. Although Suzanne still had the head of her adult female self, it was definitely smaller now – probably in proportion to her new body. Consequently, her mother’s face seemed as enormous as a face on a billboard.

“Suzanne who? What happened to Trevor?”

“I – what? Who’s Trevor?”

“My baby! Trevor! That’s what we were going to name him before – before YOU came out instead!” The woman’s look turned harsh and accusing.

“Listen, I just told you I have no idea what’s happening!” Suzanne squirmed angrily in her ‘mother’s’ unfamiliar arms. “My name is Suzanne Wong. I work at H. L. Stevens, downtown.” Suzanne said ‘downtown’, but it occurred to her that she had no idea whether she was even in the same city anymore. “The last thing I remember, I was at my desk. I just closed my eyes for a second, and next thing I knew…THIS was happening. OK? I don’t know who you are. I’ve never seen you before in my life, and I repeat that I have NO IDEA AT ALL, WHATSOEVER, how I ended up here! I know this must be a huge shock from your end, but it’s just as bad for me – and at least you got to keep your own body!”

The younger (but, er, also older) woman looked pensive for a moment. “You might be right,” she said, “in which case I’m sorry for snapping at you. I’m just very confused right now… I mean, I know you are too, I just…” she sighed. “I’m sorry. My name is Elizabeth, by the way.”

“It’s…nice to meet you, Elizabeth.” Suzanne smiled, with a sincerity that surprised her. Elizabeth. It was a nice name. Appropriate, somehow. Motherly. Suzanne couldn’t help but notice how warm the woman was, wrapped in her arms as she was. She was nestled up against her breasts – although they were enlarged from maternity, they must have been quite large even before. They were also naked, and the feeling of her mother’s bare skin against her own was, she had to admit, extremely pleasant. Is this how all babies feel when their mothers hold them? It’s wonderful… For the briefest of moments, Suzanne Wong had not a single care. Then another thought interrupted. Wait. This isn’t right. I’m not a baby. I shouldn’t be feeling like this. Suzanne shook her head. “Um…do you think you could please wipe off my glasses for me?”

“So you have no idea how you ended up here, huh?” asked Elizabeth as she gingerly wiped Suzanne’s glasses with the edge of a blanket. “And I don’t know anything either…so what do we do now?”

“Well, for the time being, I don’t know what we can do, except…get to know each other better, I suppose.”

“Well this is supposed to be the crucial time for mother-child bonding, so no better time, I guess!” Elizabeth smiled weakly. “Which makes me think of something else, actually.”

“Something else?”

Elizabeth’s eyes darted nervously away from Suzanne’s face. “Um… I need to feed you.”

“Oh.”

There was a long pause. Of course. Suzanne should have been ready for this. She’d had kids of her own, after all. She knew the routine. And she had to admit, now that she thought of it, she was feeling hungry…

“You know what? I can wait until you get a bottle warmed up.”

“There’s no point in being shy, Suzanne. I literally just pushed you out of my vagina. You still have some of my amniotic fluid in your hair! Breastfeeding you can’t be any weirder than that.”

Suzanne figured as much. She’d certainly insisted on feeding her own kids the natural way as often as possible back when they were born. It was the healthy choice. Well then, might as well get it over with.

“Alright,” said Suzanne, “give me the nipple.”

“Well, you didn’t have to say it like that.”

“Just let me have it.”

“Watch your teeth.”

Elizabeth shifted her massive breast slightly, bringing her nipple into view. Suzanne blushed at the sight of it – not because it looked like anything special, but because of what she was about to do. Looking up, she could see that Elizabeth was blushing too. Elizabeth brought the nipple into position and, after just the briefest of pauses, Suzanne placed her lips around it.

She had never tasted anything so sweet.

153332312.content:
Lana regained awareness in patches. The first thing she was aware of was that she was in bed, which was slightly odd because she remembered falling asleep at her desk the night before. She could feel her hair clip digging into the back of her head as she lay on the bed, confirming that she hadn't had the chance to undress before passing out. So then who moved me to the bed? She thought, groggily. Lana lived alone.

The second thing she noticed, which immediately had her full attention, was that the bed, and the room around it, were not hers. Everything was in the wrong place, and posters covered the walls. Some were musicians she didn't recognize, while many more were of very shapely women in various states of undress. Startled by the unfamiliar surroundings, she threw back the covers, and it was then that she noticed the third thing.

This one took a few more seconds to process. The legs were what caught her eye first - specifically, the copious brownish hair. "What the hell?" Lana said out loud. She had waxed them only last weekend, there was no way they could have - hold on. Are those boxers? Why would I be wearing those? Another person's room, another person's clothes...and another person's body. Yes, as impossible as it was, that was the truth that became apparent as Lana stared down at herself. That was the source of the strange feeling she hadn't been able to place, and why her legs looked so wrong - they weren't her legs in the first place. The white T-shirt she was also wearing presented the final piece of the puzzle. She peeked down the neck hole and confirmed what she'd already feared: No bra underneath. In fact, no breasts underneath. Breathing unsteadily, Lana stood up and tiptoed over to a mirror on the nearby dresser.

Lana knew her own head when she saw it. She liked her head; it was a very nice one. She had rich, lustrous brown hair and a beautiful face - which, when combined with her curvy and well-toned body, made her the object of quite a few student crushes. But while she saw her lovely head in the mirror, that was not her sexy body. Below her neck was the body of a teenage boy. Well, she thought, that explains the weird feeling in these boxers...


Lana's heart (or was it her heart?) was pounding. She looked down at the surface of the dresser. Peculiarly, she recognized her own makeup kit and jewelry box. But inside the jewelry box were only necklaces, earrings, hair clips, and the like - no bracelets, rings, or anything that would be worn below the neck. There was also a framed photo of a young boy, maybe 10 or 12, dressed in a little league uniform and holding a baseball bat. However, instead of the boy's proper head there was only Lana's, hair pulled back in a ponytail under the baseball cap and smiling cheerfully with lips the bright red color of her favorite lipstick.

Freaked out as she was, it was almost a miracle that Lana didn't have a heart attack when the door swung open. "Tyler! Why in God's name aren't you dressed yet?" Lana found herself staring at a heavyset middle-aged woman, likely the mother of whoever this body belonged to. She could do nothing but stand there mutely as the strange woman regarded her.

"Well?" Said the woman after a few seconds' pause. "Breakfast is ready and the bus will be here in less than 10 minutes. Get a move on!" At that she slammed the door shut, and her footsteps retreated down the hall.

It took another second or two before Lana moved again. That woman had been looking right at her, but hadn't noticed anything amiss. She hadn't seen Lana at all, only this 'Tyler'. Tyler...Tyler...that name sounds familiar. Suddenly she remembered. The last paper she remembered grading before she fell asleep was Tyler Watson's. Tyler was a bit of a problem student, and his latest grade had been yet another F. Had Lana's idle wish to understand her students better somehow caused this?
153332312.title: one of her F students

1533323121.content:
It took a while for Lana to decide on a course of action. But, the urgency Tyler's Mother created by shouting for her to hurry up caused her to snap into action much more quickly than she probably would have cared for.

She felt like she was in a waking dream, or more accurately, a living nightmare. The feel of a body other than the one she'd been born with beneath her head was as disorienting as it sounded! With a few more shouts from downstairs urging her on, Lana finally decided that her best bet for answers was to play along with being Tyler. For one thing, she HAD to find out what was going on with her original, familiar body now that her head had been transplanted and her best bet for doing so was to look for "Miss Corrales" at school.

Caught between being dazed and panicked, she got dressed in a ridiculously clumsy dash. She threw on a black t-shirt, a pair of jeans, and Tyler's Chuck Taylor sneakers. Almost without thinking, she pulled her hair back in a pony-tail, washed her face, and applied a modest amount of makeup. She tried make herself look fresh and crisp, as she would on any other school-day. Perhaps craving familiarity, she put on a pair of simple gold hoop ear-rings and scrambled downstairs.

Tyler's hefty Mother stomped around the kitchen, apparently not a morning person and in a bit of a rush herself. "It's about time. I am NOT running you to school this morning young man, so you had better not miss the bus!" she barked as she put dishes away.

An equally husky man, balding, with a bushy brown beard peered over the sports-page of the newspaper at Lana. "And I sure as Hell ain't running you in either." From his work-cloths and the hard-hat sitting on the nearby counter next to a lunch pail, Lana guessed he was a construction worker of some kind.

"Well, are you going to just stand there or what?!?!" Tyler's Mother's face was bright red now.

"Uh---Uh...that is...no...I...where does the bus stop?" Lana meekly answered, taken aback by all the hostility and at a loss as to how to react.

The woman slammed an unopened pop-tart in Lana's new hand, spun her around and pushed her toward the door. "I swear to God...what is with you?!?! Is this why your grades are in the toilet?!?! Did you fall on your head or something?!?!"

Lana was at a loss. "M-my head...?"

Tyler's Mother pushed her out the door.

Walking down the sidewalk in a daze, Lana finally looked around. To her horror, she could see a stopped school-bus a quarter of a mile down the road already loading up. Running as swiftly as she could on Tyler's young legs, she just barely made it on board, sliding into a seat as the bus pulled away from the curb.

Nervous anticipation kept Lana's mind occupied the entire ride to school. When she arrived at school, would she find her original body? If so, would she be able to figure out what had happened to her? It wasn't until the bus finally reached its destination and she stumbled off in a daze that a more immediate concern struck her: I have no idea what this kid's class schedule is. Tyler Watson - if indeed that was who this body belonged to - didn't have her class (English) until 4th period, and Lana didn't know what classes he had before or after. What was she going to do now?

Lana's heart started pounding as she tried to think. She did know that Tyler had a class with Mr. Richards at some point during the day, as she remembered hearing Tyler complain about him in her class. From a conversation she'd had with Mrs. Davis the math teacher, she knew that Tyler was a bit of a problem student in one of her classes as well. But in neither case did she know when he had those classes, and all that was still assuming that she was occupying the body of Tyler Watson and not some other Tyler. Lana wandered the halls, confused about what to do next.

"Hey, Tyler!"

A voice broke her out of her thoughts. Even as much as she was worrying about it, it still took her a second to realize that she was Tyler and that voice was directed at her. She looked up to see another student waving at her.

Headini says some words to fix Fiona and his assistant. But he says the wrong words and begins vanishing. "Oh no, I used the wrong spell!" he cries as his skin starts turning invisible. He tries to say some words to fix this, but alas, it is too late. The Great Headini has seemed to disappear.

"Headini?" his assistant says as she waves her arm where he should be. "Uh-oh."

"Does that mean we're stuck like this?" Fiona asks, scared.

"I don't know, kid."

Everyone in the audience is both amazed and shocked. Fiona's parents then run up to their daughter and the assistant. "Fiona, are you okay?" her mother asks.

"I'm fine, Mom," Fiona says.

The assistant sighs. "Looks like your daughter and I will be sharing my body for quite some time," she says.

"Where did he go?" Fiona's father asks.

"I'm not sure. This is the 5th time he's mysteriously vanished. His disappearances could take a day, or a month, or even several years. The last time he disappeared, I was stuck as a bodiless head, and my friend had to take care of me until he returned."

153332322333.content:
More Choices:

1. A 65 year old man with a neatly trimmed gray beard with a few black hairs left and bald head, named Robert Clay.

-A little back ground information of this character. Throughout his life he didn't care much what he did to and put in body as a result of his careless life style his body was failing him. He had many visits to the hospital for health related problems such heart attacks and diabetes. Soon his body was on its last leg and he knew it and cried as he laid there in the hospital bed thinking about how he could have changed his way of life much earlier he wouldn't be in this situation. He was surrounded by his loved ones telling that he will live on, but that's all they could do, so later that day a few specialist came in and surrounded him telling him about an experimental surgery that could potentially let him live a longer life, does Robert agree or disagree?

2. A young man of 21 with short dark brown hair and brown eyes named Trevor Aiken.

-Came to a realization that he might never find the love of his life ever and that he doesn't have much of a life. He knew that he had a long life a head of him, but what's the point living on. That same day he had planned on taking his own life and was all prepared for it that night, but an event occurred the same time that had interrupted him. He looked out of bedroom window in the field of his father's farm and saw three familiar shaped figures standing there. The shape of them was that of your typical alien and it had intrigued him to the point he wanted to get close to them, but does he or not?
